elements.content: Two new directly attached carboranyl-indenyl compounds, 2-(o-carboranyl)indene (2) and 1-(o-carboranyl)indene (4), were synthesized, and their applications in lanthanide chemistry were explored. Reactions of 2-indanone or indene epoxide with Li2C2B10H10 followed by dehydration reactions gave 2 or 4, respectively. Treatment of 2 with excess sodium metal afforded presumably {η5:η6-(2-C9H6)(C2B10H11)}{Na3(THF) n }, which reacted with LnCl3 to produce dinuclear complexes [{η5:η6-(2-C9H6)(C2B10H11)Ln(THF)}2(μ-Cl)][Na(THF)6] (Ln = Y (5a), Er (5b)). Compound 4 reacted with excess sodium metal, yielding [{η5:η6-(1-C9H6)(C2B10H11)}{Na3(THF)5}]2 (6), bearing a six-membered C2B4 open face and a five-membered C5 bonding face. Reaction of 6 with LnCl3 or Ln(BH4)3(THF)3 gave [{η5:η6-(1-C9H6)(C2B10H11)Ln(THF)}2(μ-Cl)][Na(THF)3] (Ln = Y (7a), Nd (7b), Er (7c)) or {[η5:η6-(1-C9H6)(C2B10H11)Er(THF)]2(μ-BH4)}{Na(THF)2} (8), respectively. Interaction of 8 with excess sodium metal generated {[η5:η7-(1-C9H6)(C2B10H11)Er(THF)]2}{Na4(THF)8} (9). These new complexes were characterized by various spectroscopic techniques and elemental analyses. The molecular structures of 1−4, 5b, 6, 7a, 7c, 8, and 9 were confirmed by single-crystal X-ray analyses. The results showed that these new ligands favored the formation of the “metal-bridged” type of dinuclear complexes due to the lack of the linkage between the indenyl and carboranyl units.

elements.content:
New directly linked carboranyl-indenyl ligands were prepared. They favor the formation of metal-bridged dinuclear complexes in which the metal bonds to the cage in either η 6- or η 7-fashion.

Introduction

Ligands are an essential part of organometallic compounds. They impose a dominant control over both the chemical and the physical properties of the resulting metal complexes. Therefore, ligand design has become a central theme in the development of the chemistry of organometallic compounds. In this connection, a series of single-atom-bridged cyclopentadienyl-, indenyl-, and fluorenyl-carboranyl ligands, A(C5H5)(C2B10H11) (A = Me2C, Me2Si), A‘(C9H7)(C2B10H11) (A‘ = Me2C, Me2Si, Pr i 2NB, Pr i 2NP), and A‘ ‘(C13H9)(C2B10H11) (A‘ ‘ = H2C, Me2Si), have been developed. These ligands are finding many applications in organometallic chemistry. Experimental results show that the bridging atom significantly influences the chemical and physical properties of the resulting organometallic complexes. It is anticipated that the interactions between a cyclic organic moiety and a carboranyl group would be largely enhanced if there is not any linkage between them, probably leading to a new class of ligands demanding highly constrained geometries.

In this connection, a series of single-atom-bridged cyclopentadienyl-, indenyl-, and fluorenyl-carboranyl ligands, A(C5H5)(C2B10H11) (A = Me2C, Me2Si), A‘(C9H7)(C2B10H11) (A‘ = Me2C, Me2Si, Pr i   2NB, Pr i   2NP), and A‘‘(C13H9)(C2B10H11) (A‘‘ = H2C, Me2Si), have been developed. These ligands are finding many applications in organometallic chemistry. Experimental results show that the bridging atom significantly influences the chemical and physical properties of the resulting organometallic complexes. It is anticipated that the interactions between a cyclic organic moiety and a carboranyl group would be largely enhanced if there is not any linkage between them, probably leading to a new class of ligands demanding highly constrained geometries.

elements.content: Cyclopentadiene-substituted o-carboranes are known. They are prepared from either the direct reaction of LiC2B10H10R with cyclopentenone followed by dehydration11b or the intramolecular cyclization of 1-Ph-2-[CH(CH2CH2C6H5)2]-1,2-C2B10H10. Organometallic complexes directly derived from these compounds have not appeared in the literature yet, although some sandwich/half-sandwich complexes were reported (A−C, in Chart ). These species were prepared from the reaction of ethynylferrocene with decaborane12a or (η5-C5D5)RuCl(PPh3)2 with 1-Li-2-Me-1,2-C2B10H10 12b or RuCl2(PPh3)3 with Li2[Me2C(C5H4) (C2B10H10)]. The mechanisms for the formation of B and C were not clear. To investigate the properties of directly linked indenyl-carboranyl compounds and to compare them with the corresponding single-atom-bridged systems, we prepared 2-(o-carboranyl)indene and 1-(o-carboranyl)indene and investigated their applications in organolanthanide chemistry. These results are reported in this article.

Ligands. Our objective was to directly connect the carboranyl moiety to the indenyl group with the cage CH available for further functionalization. Some indenyl derivatives were conveniently prepared from the reaction of indenyllithium with electrophiles. Unfortunately, 1-I-1,2-C2B10H11 showed no reactivity toward indenyllithium. In view of the nucleophilicity of readily available Li2C2B10H10, several electrophilic compounds were examined. The results showed that the reaction of Li2C2B10H10 with secondary halides such as 3-bromoindene afforded very poor yields, probably due to the relatively low nucleophilicity of the carborane anion. After many attempts, it was found that very strong electrophiles of indanone and indene epoxide were suitable starting materials.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

 Ligands. Our objective was to directly connect the carboranyl moiety to the indenyl group with the cage CH available for further functionalization. Some indenyl derivatives were conveniently prepared from the reaction of indenyllithium with electrophiles. Unfortunately, 1-I-1,2-C2B10H11 showed no reactivity toward indenyllithium. In view of the nucleophilicity of readily available Li2C2B10H10, several electrophilic compounds were examined. The results showed that the reaction of Li2C2B10H10 with secondary halides such as 3-bromoindene afforded very poor yields, probably due to the relatively low nucleophilicity of the carborane anion. After many attempts, it was found that very strong electrophiles of indanone and indene epoxide were suitable starting materials.

elements.content: Treatment of 2-indanone with 1 equiv of Li2C2B10H10 at room temperature afforded, after column chromatographic separation, 2-(o-carboranyl)-2-indanol (1) and o-carborane in 31% and 56% yields, respectively. The 11B NMR experiments indicated that only 40% of Li2C2B10H10 was consumed before quenching the reaction with a diluted HCl solution. The yield of 1 was not improved even under forced reaction conditions. A stronger electrophile was necessary to increase the efficiency of this nucleophilic reaction. Reaction of indene epoxide with 1 equiv of Li2C2B10H10 in diethyl ether gave 1-(o-carboranyl)-2-indanol (3) in 82% yield. Although the β-position is sterically more accessible, it is a much less reactive site than α-carbon toward nucleophiles due to the presence of the aromatic ring. Therefore, no other isomer was isolated.

The 11B NMR experiments indicated that only 40% of Li2C2B10H10 was consumed before quenching the reaction with a diluted HCl solution. The yield of 1 was not improved even under forced reaction conditions. A stronger electrophile was necessary to increase the efficiency of this nucleophilic reaction. Reaction of indene epoxide with 1 equiv of Li2C2B10H10 in diethyl ether gave 1-(o-carboranyl)-2-indanol (3) in 82% yield. Although the β-position is sterically more accessible, it is a much less reactive site than α-carbon toward nucleophiles due to the presence of the aromatic ring. Therefore, no other isomer was isolated.

elements.content: There are many methods to convert alcohols to olefins. Compound 1 is very stable in acidic media under normal reaction conditions. After many attempts, it was found that a very strong acid and high temperature were required to convert 1 into the corresponding indene derivative. Heating the mixture of 1 and p-TsOH in a molar ratio of 1:1 in a sealed Pyrex tube at 180 °C for 10 min gave, after workup, 2-(o-carboranyl)indene (2) in 84% yield (Scheme ). On the other hand, compound 3 is surprisingly stable under various acidic conditions. Direct dehydration of 3 is not feasible. Alternative routes were then examined. Treatment of 3 with a mixture of triphenylphosphine, imidazole, and iodine in a molar ratio of 1:1.2:2:1.3 in refluxing toluene for 48 h generated, after workup, 1-(o-carboranyl)indene (4) in 78% yield (Scheme ). The thermodynamically more stable compound 4 was the only isomer. No 3-(o-carboranyl)indene was isolated. Compounds 1 and 3 are soluble in Et2O, THF, and toluene and slightly soluble in n-hexane, whereas 2 and 4 are soluble in common organic solvents including n-hexane.

In addition to the aromatic protons, two doublets at 3.52 and 2.97 ppm with 2 J = 16.2 Hz assignable to the axial and equatorial protons at the benzyl positions, one singlet at 4.29 ppm attributable to the cage CH proton, and one broad singlet at 2.42 ppm corresponding to the OH group were observed in the 1H NMR spectrum of 1. For 2, the 1H NMR spectrum showed three singlets at 7.02 (vinyl proton), 3.89 (cage CH proton), and 3.54 ppm (benzyl protons) besides the aromatic protons. Their 13C NMR spectra were consistent with the 1H NMR results. The 11B NMR spectra exhibited a 2:2:2:4 splitting pattern for 1 and a 1:1:2:2:2:2 splitting pattern for 2. The solid-state IR spectrum of 1 displayed a characteristic broad, strong absorption of OH at 3571 cm-1 and a very strong absorption of BH at ca. 2600 cm-1. The characteristic OH absorption disappeared in the IR spectrum of 2, but that of BH remained.

For 2, the 1H NMR spectrum showed three singlets at 7.02 (vinyl proton), 3.89 (cage CH proton), and 3.54 ppm (benzyl protons) besides the aromatic protons. elements.content: The 3 J coupling constants of trans protons are too small to be observed in the 1H NMR spectrum of 3 since the dihedral angles between the trans protons are close to 90°. Accordingly, a singlet at 3.88 ppm of the tertiary CH (benzyl) proton, a doublet at 4.77 ppm of the tertiary CH(OH) proton with 3 J = 5.1 Hz, a doublet at 2.81 ppm of one methylene proton with 2 J = 17.1 Hz, and a doublet of doublets at 3.45 ppm of another methylene proton with coupling constants of 2 J = 17.1 and 3 J = 5.1 Hz were observed in the 1H NMR spectrum of 3. A singlet at 3.58 ppm corresponding to the cage CH proton and a broad singlet at 1.72 ppm assignable to the OH proton were also observed. The latter disappeared after adding D2O to the NMR solution, confirming that it was an OH proton. The 1H NMR spectrum of 4 was relatively simple, showing a triplet at 6.84 ppm with 3 J = 2.1 Hz of the vinyl proton, a doublet at 3.41 ppm with 3 J = 2.1 Hz of the methylene protons, and a singlet at 4.14 ppm of the cage CH proton, in addition to the aromatic protons. The 11B NMR spectra exhibited a 1:1:2:3:3 splitting pattern for 3 and 1:1:2:4:2 for 4, respectively. Their solid-state IR spectra displayed a very strong characteristic peak of BH absorption at ca. 2600 cm-1. A broad, strong absorption of an OH group at 3335 cm-1 was also observed in the IR spectrum of 3.

elements.content: The solid-state structures of 1−4 were further confirmed by single-crystal X-ray analyses. The selected bond distances and angles are listed in Table . The molecular structure of 1 (Figure ) shows that both the cage and OH group are bonded to C(11). The bond distances and angles indicate that C(11), C(12), and C(19) are all sp3-carbons, whereas C(13) and C(18) are sp2-carbons. In the molecular structure of 2 (Figure ), the C(11) and C(12) become sp2-carbons with a bond distance of 1.387(2) Å. The C(11)−C(1) distance of 1.489(2) Å is much shorter than that of 1.554(2) Å observed in 1, indicative of a certain degree of conjugation between the cage and indenyl group.

There are two crystallographically independent molecules in the unit cell of 3. Figure shows the representative structure. It is clear that the OH group and the cage are in trans arrangement. The C−C distances are very close to those observed in 1. The C(11) and C(19) become the sp2-carbons in 4 (Figure ), as judged from the bond distances and angles listed in Table . The C(1)−C(11) distance of 1.493(3) Å is very close to that of 1.489(2) Å in 2 but is much shorter than the 1.545(3) [1.547(3)] Å in 3, again suggestive of some conjugation between the indenyl and carboranyl units. These results clearly imply that the interactions between the indenyl and cage are stronger than those observed in single-atom-bridged systems.

elements.content: Organolanthanide Complexes. Compounds 2 and 4 are isomers bearing two functional moieties that can be conveniently converted into π ligands. Treatment of 2 with excess finely cut sodium metal at room temperature in THF for 48 h generated, after removal of excess Na, presumably a {η5:η6-(2-C9H6)(C2B10H11)}{Na3(THF) n } solution, followed by reaction with 1 equiv of LnCl3 to give [{η5:η6-(2-C9H6)(C2B10H11)Ln(THF)}2(μ-Cl)][Na(THF)6] (Ln = Y (5a), Er (5b)) in about 70% isolated yield (Scheme ). The same complexes were isolated even when the molar ratio of 2:LnCl3 was changed from 1:1 to 1:2. The diamagnetic yttrium complex 5a offered useful NMR information. Its 1H NMR indicated the presence of an indenyl group and THF and supported a molar ratio of four THF molecules per indenyl. The 11B NMR spectrum showed a 1:2:4:2:1 splitting pattern. These data, however, do not offer any structural information on whether 5a is a monomeric or dimeric species. An X-ray analysis is desired.

A single-crystal X-ray diffraction study revealed that 5b is a dinuclear molecule consisting of well-separated, alternating layers of discrete complex cations [Na(THF)6]+ and dinuclear anions [{η5:η6-(2-C9H6)(C2B10H11)Er(THF)}2(μ-Cl)]-. In the anion, each Er atom is η6-bound to the nido-carboranyl, η5-bound to the indenyl, σ-bound to one doubly bridging Cl atom, and coordinated to one THF molecule in a distorted-tetrahedral geometry, as shown in Figure . The selected bond distances and angles are listed in Table . Thus 5a and 5b are metal-bridged type of complexes in which the same ligand bonds to two metal atoms due to the highly constrained system. The dihedral angles between the five- and six-membered bonding faces in the same ligand are 13.8° and 14.8°, respectively.

In the anion, each Er atom is η6-bound to the nido-carboranyl, η5-bound to the indenyl, σ-bound to one doubly bridging Cl atom, and coordinated to one THF molecule in a distorted-tetrahedral geometry, as shown in Figure . The average Er−cage atom distance of 2.715(16) Å and Er−C5 ring distance of 2.669(15) Å are comparable to the corresponding values of 2.680(3) and 2.602(5) Å in [η5:η6-Me2C(C5H4)(C2B10H11)]Er(THF)2 2b,15 and 2.773(12) and 2.675(15) Å in [{η5:η6-Me2Si(C9H6)(C2B10H11)}Er(THF)(μ-Cl)Na(THF)2] n . The Cent6−Er−Cent5 (Cent6 and Cent5 represent the centroids of the six- and five-membered bonding faces, respectively) angle of 132.3° is significantly larger than the chelating type of complexes, for example, 118.4° in [η5:η6-Me2C(C5H4)(C2B10H11)]Er(THF)2 and 126.1° in [{η5:η6-Me2Si(C9H6)(C2B10H11)}Er(THF)(μ-Cl)Na(THF)2] n . The average Er−Cl distance of 2.633(4) Å is significantly shorter than that of 2.733(1) Å in [{η5:η7-Me2C(C5H4)(C2B10H11)}Er2(μ-Cl)(THF)3]2, but much longer than that of 2.545(1) Å in [{η5:σ-Me2Si(C9H6)(C2B10H10)}{η5-Me2Si(C9H6)(C2B10H11)}]Er(μ-Cl)Na(THF)3 5b and 2.563(4) Å in [{η5:η6-Me2Si(C9H6)(C2B10H11)}Er(THF)(μ-Cl)Na(THF)2] n . The C(1)−C(11)/C(1‘)−C(11‘) bond distances of 1.449(19)/1.497(18) Å in 5b are close to that of 1.489(2) Å in 2.

elements.content: Like 2, reduction of 4 with excess Na metal in THF at room temperature for 24 h afforded [{η5:η6-(1-C9H6)(C2B10H11)}{Na3(THF)5}]2 (6) in 92% yield. Its 11B NMR spectrum displayed a 3:4:3 splitting pattern, which was significantly different from that of 4. Therefore, this reduction reaction was closely followed by the 11B NMR. Its 1H NMR spectrum showed the presence of the ligand and supported a molar ratio of five THF molecules per indenyl group. The solid-state structure of 6 was further confirmed by single-crystal X-ray analysis and is shown in Figure . It has a centrosymmetrical structure, in which the trianionic ligand is bonded to two Na atoms via the six- and five-membered rings in η6- and η5-fashion and to the third Na atom through one Na···B−H and one Na−(η2-C(15)C(16)) interaction, respectively. The average Na(1)−cage atom distance of 2.775(6) Å is very close to that of 2.776(2) Å in closo-exo-[(C6H5CH2)2C2B10H10]Na2(THF)4, but is much shorter than that of 2.854(4) Å in [{μ-1,2-[o-C6H4-(CH2)2)]-1,2-C2B10H10}2Na4(THF)6] n and 2.848(7) Å in [{η6-[(CH3OCH2CH2)2C2B10H10]Na}{Na(THF)}] n . The average Na(2)−C5 ring distance of 2.831(6) Å is much shorter than that of 2.934(3) Å in [η5-Me2Si(C9H6)(C2B10H11)]Yb(THF)[(μ-η5):σ-Me2Si(C9H6)(C2B10H10)]Na(THF)3 5a and 2.877(1) Å in [NaC9H7(15-crown-5)].

elements.content: Interaction of 6 with 2 or 4 equiv of LnCl3 in THF at room temperature afforded [{η5:η6-(1-C9H6)(C2B10H11)Ln(THF)}2(μ-Cl)][Na(THF)3] (Ln = Y (7a), Nd (7b), Er (7c)) in 75−83% yields (Scheme ). The 1H NMR spectrum of the diamagnetic complex 7a showed four doublets and two triplets in the aromatic region, a singlet at 4.26 ppm corresponding to the two cage CH protons, and two multiplets at 3.64 and 1.60 ppm attributable to the THF protons, and supported a molar ratio of 2.5 THF molecules per ligand. Its 11B NMR spectrum exhibited a 1:1:2:2:1:1:1:1 splitting pattern, which is quite different from that of 6. Again, this reaction was closely monitored by 11B NMR spectroscopy.

Its 11B NMR spectrum exhibited a 1:1:2:2:1:1:1:1 splitting pattern, which is quite different from that of 6. Again, this reaction was closely monitored by 11B NMR spectroscopy.

<label>4</label>
<graphic xlink:href="om-2006-001955_0012.tif"></graphic>
</fig>

Single-crystal X-ray analyses revealed that 7a and 7c are isomorphous and isostructural, consisting of well-separated, alternating layers of discrete complex cations [Na(THF)3]+ and anions [{η5:η6-(1-C9H6)(C2B10H11)Ln(THF)}2(μ-Cl)]-. The representative structure of 7c is shown in Figure . The anion is a metal-bridged14 centrosymmetrical dinuclear complex with a coordination environment and geometry very similar to that observed in 5b. These results indicate that both 2 and 4 form the same type of metal complexes. The dihedral angles between the six- and five-membered bonding faces of 25.5° in 7a and 26.6° in 7c are significantly larger than the corresponding values of 13.8° and 14.8° found in 5b. Consequently, the C(1)−C(11) distances of 1.515(1) Å in 7a and 1.495(2) Å in 7c are statistically longer than those of 1.497(18) and 1.449(19) Å in 5b, which might reflect some differences in conjugation between the two π systems.

elements.content: Organolanthanide chloride complexes are generally useful starting materials for the synthesis of the corresponding complexes containing Ln−X (X = H, C, N, O, S, P, BH4) bonds. We examined the chemical properties of 5a and 7a. They were surprisingly inert toward nucleophiles such as NaBH4, CH3COONa, Na[CH3COCHCOCH3], and KOBu t and toward chlorine-abstracting reagents such as AgOTf and AgNO3. To help understand these results, the space-filling drawing of the anion in 7c was generated using X-ray data (Figure ). The figure clearly shows that the coordination sphere of the lanthanide ion is fully occupied by the surrounding ligands, which prevents the metal ion from any attack of nucleophiles. On the other hand, although the bridging Cl atom is accessible by Ag+, such interactions may not be strong enough to break the Ln−Cl−Ln bonds.

We examined the chemical properties of 5a and 7a. They were surprisingly inert toward nucleophiles such as NaBH4, CH3COONa, Na[CH3COCHCOCH3], and KOBu t   and toward chlorine-abstracting reagents such as AgOTf and AgNO3. To help understand these results, the space-filling drawing of the anion in 7c was generated using X-ray data (Figure ). The figure clearly shows that the coordination sphere of the lanthanide ion is fully occupied by the surrounding ligands, which prevents the metal ion from any attack of nucleophiles. On the other hand, although the bridging Cl atom is accessible by Ag+, such interactions may not be strong enough to break the Ln-Cl-Ln bonds.

elements.content: To prepare derivatives of 7c, an alternate synthetic route was desired. Reaction of 6 with Er(BH4)3(THF)3 in a molar ratio of 1:2 in THF at room temperature gave the BH4 --bridged dinuclear complex {[η5:η6-(1-C9H6)(C2B10H11)Er(THF)]2(μ-BH4)}{Na(THF)2} (8) in 74% yield. Treatment of 8 with excess sodium metal in THF at room temperature afforded the BH4 --free dinuclear complex {[η5:η7-(1-C9H6)(C2B10H11)Er(THF)]2}{Na4(THF)8} (9) in 68% yield, as shown in Scheme . The formation of the insoluble NaBH4 in THF facilitated the purification of 9. Both 8 and 9 are paramagnetic complexes and do not provide interpretable NMR spectra. Their structures were, however, ultimately established by single-crystal X-ray diffraction studies.

Treatment of 8 with excess sodium metal in THF at room temperature afforded the BH4 --free dinuclear complex {[η5:η7-(1-C9H6)(C2B10H11)Er(THF)]2}{Na4(THF)8} (9) in 68% yield, as shown in Scheme . The formation of the insoluble NaBH4 in THF facilitated the purification of 9. Both 8 and 9 are paramagnetic complexes and do not provide interpretable NMR spectra. Their structures were, however, ultimately established by single-crystal X-ray diffraction studies.

<fig fig-type="scheme" id="om0601955h00005" position="float">
<label>5</label>
<graphic xlink:href="om-2006-001955_0014.tif"></graphic>
</fig>

Complex 8 adopts the polymeric structure in which the Na+ ions serve as linkages to connect the dinuclear complex anions [{η5:η6-(1-C9H6)(C2B10H11)Er(THF)}2(μ-BH4)]- to form zigzag infinite polymeric chains. Overall, the structure of the anion is similar to that observed in 7c except for the bridging BH4 - unit, as shown in Figure . The hydrogen atoms of the BH4 - group cannot be located from X-ray data, which prevents the precise assignment of the coordination mode of the BH4 - group. Since B(41) is almost located at the middle of the two Er atoms (Table ), it is reasonable to suggest that the BH4 - moiety bonds to the two Er atoms in the same coordination mode, which may be determined according to the Er−B distances. For η2-BH4 -, the Ln−B distances are normally in the range 2.65−2.78 Å. In view of the Er−B(41) distances of 2.645(5) and 2.667(5) Å, it is best suggested that the BH4 - group is η2-bonded to two Er atoms to form a Er(μ-H)2B(μ-H)2Er unit.

elements.content: An X-ray analysis revealed that 9 is a coordination polymer in which the Na+ ions act as linkages to connect the complex anions [η5:η7-(1-C9H6)(C2B10H11)Er(THF)]2 4- to generate two-dimensional coordination sheets. The anion is a centrosymmetrical dinuclear complex, shown in Figure . Each Er atom is η7-bound to the arachno-carboranyl, η5-bound to the indenyl unit of the other ligand, and coordinated to one THF molecule in an almost trigonal planar geometry. Such an arrangement has not been observed before in lanthanacarboranes incorporating an arachno-carboranyl ligand. The average Er−C5 ring distance of 2.716(7) Å compares to that of 2.683(5) Å in 8 and 2.758(5) Å in [{η5:η7-[Me2Si(C9H6)(C2B10H11)]Er}2{Na4(THF)8}] n . The Er−C(1,4) distances of 2.375(6) and 2.364(8) Å and the average Er−cage B distance of 2.703(8) Å are comparable to those of 2.386(5) and 2.655(7) Å in [{η5:η7-Me2C(C5H4)(C2B10H11)}Er2(μ-Cl)(THF)3]2, 2.410(6) and 2.671(7) Å in [{[η5:η7-Me2C(C5H4)(C2B10H11)]Er}2{Na4(THF)9}] n , and 2.421(5) and 2.739(5) Å in [{η5:η7-[Me2Si(C9H6)(C2B10H11)]Er}2{Na4(THF)8}] n .

elements.content: Two new directly attached carboranyl-indenyl ligands were synthesized and structurally characterized. They were readily converted into the trianions bearing an open six-membered C2B4 face and a C5 ring that are directly connected to each other. The lack of the linkage between the two bonding faces makes these trianions highly constrained, favoring the formation of metal-bridged dinuclear complexes with lanthanides, for example, [{η5:η6-(C9H6)(C2B10H11)Ln(THF)}2(μ-X)][Na(THF) n ]. The nido-C2B10H11 unit in these complexes was able to be further reduced to the arachno-C2B10H11 ligand by Na metal. Accordingly, another type of metal-bridged dinuclear complex, {[η5:η7-(1-C9H6)(C2B10H11)Er(THF)]2}{Na4(THF)8}, was prepared and structurally characterized. These results indicate that the coordination mode exhibited by the new ligands [(C9H6)C2B10H11]3- is similar to that of the [(C5H4)C6H5]- ligand, but is different from the single-atom-bridged systems [A(C9H6)(C2B10H11)]3- (A = Me2C, Me2Si). The reactivity of (C9H7)C2B10H11 is, however, very similar to that of A(C9H6)(C2B10H11).
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

Two new directly attached carboranyl-indenyl ligands were synthesized and structurally characterized. They were readily converted into the trianions bearing an open six-membered C2B4 face and a C5 ring that are directly connected to each other. The lack of the linkage between the two bonding faces makes these trianions highly constrained, favoring the formation of metal-bridged dinuclear complexes with lanthanides, for example, [{η5:η6-(C9H6)(C2B10H11)Ln(THF)}2(μ-X)][Na(THF) n ]. The nido-C2B10H11 unit in these complexes was able to be further reduced to the arachno-C2B10H11 ligand by Na metal. Accordingly, another type of metal-bridged dinuclear complex, {[η5:η7-(1-C9H6)(C2B10H11)Er(THF)]2}{Na4(THF)8}, was prepared and structurally characterized. These results indicate that the coordination mode exhibited by the new ligands [(C9H6)C2B10H11]3- is similar to that of the [(C5H4)C6H5]- ligand, but is different from the single-atom-bridged systems [A(C9H6)(C2B10H11)]3- (A = Me2C, Me2Si). The reactivity of (C9H7)C2B10H11 is, however, very similar to that of A(C9H6)(C2B10H11).

elements.content: General Procedures. All experiments were performed under an atmosphere of dry nitrogen with the rigid exclusion of air and moisture using standard Schlenk or cannula techniques, or in a glovebox. All organic solvents were freshly distilled from sodium benzophenone ketyl immediately prior to use. Li2C2B10H10, 2-indanone, indene epoxide, anhydrous LnCl3, and Ln(BH4)3(THF)3 were prepared according to the literature methods. All other chemicals were purchased from Aldrich Chemical Co. and used as received unless otherwise noted. Infrared spectra were obtained from KBr pellets prepared in the glovebox on a Perkin-Elmer 1600 Fourier transform spectrometer. 1H and 13C NMR spectra were recorded on a Bruker DPX 300 spectrometer at 300.13 and 75.47 MHz, respectively. 11B NMR spectra were recorded on a Varian Inova 400 spectrometer at 128.32 MHz. All chemical shifts were reported in δ units with reference to the residual protons of the deuterated solvents for proton and carbon chemical shifts and to external BF3·OEt2 (0.00 ppm) for boron chemical shifts. Elemental analyses were performed by MEDAC Ltd. Brunel University, Middlesex, U.K., or Shanghai Institute of Organic Chemistry, CAS, China.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

 General Procedures. All experiments were performed under an atmosphere of dry nitrogen with the rigid exclusion of air and moisture using standard Schlenk or cannula techniques, or in a glovebox. All organic solvents were freshly distilled from sodium benzophenone ketyl immediately prior to use. Li2C2B10H10, 2-indanone, indene epoxide, anhydrous LnCl3, and Ln(BH4)3(THF)3  were prepared according to the literature methods. All other chemicals were purchased from Aldrich Chemical Co. and used as received unless otherwise noted. Infrared spectra were obtained from KBr pellets prepared in the glovebox on a Perkin-Elmer 1600 Fourier transform spectrometer. 1H and 13C NMR spectra were recorded on a Bruker DPX 300 spectrometer at 300.13 and 75.47 MHz, respectively. 11B NMR spectra were recorded on a Varian Inova 400 spectrometer at 128.32 MHz. All chemical shifts were reported in δ units with reference to the residual protons of the deuterated solvents for proton and carbon chemical shifts and to external BF3⋅OEt2 (0.00 ppm) for boron chemical shifts. Elemental analyses were performed by MEDAC Ltd. Brunel University, Middlesex, U.K., or Shanghai Institute of Organic Chemistry, CAS, China.

elements.content: Preparation of 2-( o -Carboranyl)-2-indanol (1). A 1.6 M solution of n-BuLi in n-hexane (13.0 mL, 20.8 mmol) was slowly added to a stirring solution of o-carborane (1.50 g, 10.4 mmol) in toluene/diethyl ether (2:1, 30 mL) at 0 °C, and the mixture was stirred at room temperature for 2 h. The resulting Li2C2B10H10 solution was then cooled to −78 °C, to which was added 2-indanone (1.37 g, 10.4 mmol) in one portion. The reaction mixture was stirred at −78 °C for 1 h, at −30 °C for 2 h, and then at room temperature overnight. This solution was quenched by adding 2 M hydrochloric acid (15 mL). The organic layer was separated and washed by water (15 mL), saturated NaHCO3 aqueous solution (15 mL), and brine (15 mL) and then dried with anhydrous Na2SO4. After removal of the solvent, column chromatographic separation (silicon gel, 230−400 mesh) using hexane/acetone (5:1 in v/v) as eluent afforded 1 (890 mg, 31%) and o-carborane (840 mg, 56%) all as a white solid. Recrystallization from n-hexane/diethyl ether gave X-ray-quality crystals of 1, mp 110−111 °C. 1H NMR (CDCl3):  δ 7.26 (m, 4H) (aromatic), 4.29 (s, 1H) (CH of cage), 3.52 (d, 2 J = 16.2 Hz, 2H) (CH 2), 2.97 (d, 2 J = 16.2 Hz, 2H) (CH 2), 2.42 (brs, 1H) (OH). 13C{1H} NMR (CDCl3):  δ 139.0, 127.5, 125.0 (aromatic H), 81.8, 80.1 (cage C), 59.4 (C-OH), 48.8 (CH2). 11B{1H} NMR (CDCl3):  δ −3.8 (2B), −9.3 (2B), −11.9 (2B), −13.7 (4B). IR (KBr, cm-1):  ν 3571 (brs), 3065 (s), 2627 (vs), 2579 (vs), 2549 (vs), 1479 (m), 1223 (m), 1184 (m), 1092 (m), 1049 (m), 748 (vs), 723 (s). Anal. Calcd for C11H20B10O (1):  C, 47.80; H, 7.29. Found:  C, 47.44; H, 7.31.

The tube was sealed and heated at 180 °C for 10 min. The resulting black residue was dissolved in diethyl ether (10 mL). elements.content: Preparation of 1-( o -Carboranyl)indene (4). Compound 3 (1.38 g, 5.0 mmol) was dissolved in 20 mL of toluene, to which was added triphenylphosphine (1.57 g, 6.0 mmol) and imidazole (680 mg, 10.0 mmol). The suspension was stirred at room temperature until a clear solution was obtained. Iodine powder (1.65 g, 6.5 mmol) was then added in several portions. The reaction mixture was stirred at room temperature for 1 h and heated to reflux for 48 h. The resulting solid was removed by filtration. The clear filtrate was washed with 5% H2O2 (15 mL), water (15 mL), 2 M hydrochloric acid (15 mL), water (15 mL), saturated Na2S2O3 aqueous solution (15 mL), saturated NaHCO3 aqueous solution (15 mL), and brine (15 mL), respectively, and dried with anhydrous Na2SO4. Removal of the solvent afforded a brown oil. Column chromatographic separation (silicon gel, 230−400 mesh) using n-hexane as eluent produced 4 as a white solid (1.01 g, 78%). Recrystallization from n-hexane gave X-ray-quality crystals of 4, mp 136−137 °C. 1H NMR (CDCl3):  δ 7.76 (d, 3 J = 7.8 Hz, 1H), 7.48 (d, 3 J = 7.8 Hz, 1H), 7.33 (m, 2H) (aromatic), 6.84 (t, 3 J = 2.1 Hz, 1H) (vinyl), 4.14 (s, 1H) (CH of cage), 3.41 (d, 3 J = 2.1 Hz, 2H) (CH 2). 13C{1H} NMR (CDCl3):  δ 144.2, 140.8, 137.3, 137.0, 126.5, 125.8, 124.4, 121.1 (aromatic and vinyl), 72.2 (cage C), 60.7 (cage CH), 37.6 (CH2). 11B{1H} NMR (CDCl3):  δ −2.2 (1B), −3.6 (1B), −9.0 (2B), −10.9 (4B), −13.0 (2B). IR (KBr, cm-1):  ν 3077 (m), 2578 (vs), 1452 (m), 1370 (m), 1068 (m), 1008 (m), 927 (m), 814 (m), 734 (s). Anal. Calcd for C11H18B10 (4):  C, 51.14; H, 7.02. Found:  C, 50.98; H, 7.17.

elements.content: Preparation of [{ η 5 : η 6 -(2-C 9 H 6 )(C 2 B 10 H 11 )Y(THF)} 2 ( μ -Cl)][Na(THF) 6 ] (5a). A suspension of 2 (129 mg, 0.5 mmol) and finely cut sodium metal (115 mg, 5.0 mmol) in THF (5 mL) was stirred at room temperature for 24 h. After removal of excess Na metal, the clear solution was added dropwise to a suspension of YCl3 (98 mg, 0.5 mmol) in THF (3 mL). The mixture was then stirred at room temperature for 2 days. After removal of the precipitate, the resulting clear solution was concentrated to ca. 3 mL, to which was added n-hexane (1 mL). Complex 5a was collected as yellow crystals after this solution stood at room temperature for a week (232 mg, 66%), mp 82 °C (dec). 1H NMR (pyridine-d 5):  δ 8.12 (s, 2H), 7.96 (d, 3 J = 8.1 Hz, 2H), 7.03 (t, 3 J = 8.1 Hz, 2H), 6.97 (s, 2H), 6.73 (t, 3 J = 8.1 Hz, 2H), 6.24 (d, 3 J = 8.1 Hz, 2H) (indenyl), 4.07 (s, 2H) (CH of cage), 3.64 (s, 32H), 1.61 (s, 32H) (THF). 13C{1H} NMR (pyridine-d 5):  δ 145.2, 133.3, 129.0, 126.1, 124.3, 122.1, 121.5, 103.5, 98.5 (indenyl), 54.4 (cage CH), 67.2, 25.1 (THF). 11B{1H} NMR (pyridine-d 5):  δ 9.1 (2B), 2.0 (4B), −4.7 (8B), −8.3 (4B), −12.9 (2B). IR (KBr, cm-1):  ν 2965 (s), 2876 (s), 2525 (vs), 1454 (m), 1351 (m), 1105 (m), 1046 (s), 865 (m), 813 (m), 744 (m), 627 (m). Anal. Calcd for C44H78B20ClNaO5.5Y2 (5a − 2.5THF):  C, 46.05; H, 6.85. elements.content: X-ray Structure Determination. All single crystals were immersed in Paraton-N oil and sealed under nitrogen in thin-walled glass capillaries. Data were collected at 293 K on a Bruker SMART 1000 CCD diffractometer using Mo Kα radiation. An empirical absorption correction was applied using the SADABS program. All structures were solved by direct methods and subsequent Fourier difference techniques and refined anisotropically for all non-hydrogen atoms by full-matrix least-squares on F 2 using the SHELXTL program package. All hydrogen atoms were geometrically fixed using the riding model. Crystal data and details of data collection and structure refinements are given in Tables and , respectively. Further details are included in the Supporting Information.

Preparation of 2-( o -Carboranyl)-2-indanol (1). A 1.6 M solution of n-BuLi in n-hexane (13.0 mL, 20.8 mmol) was slowly added to a stirring solution of o-carborane (1.50 g, 10.4 mmol) in toluene/diethyl ether (2:1, 30 mL) at 0 °C, and the mixture was stirred at room temperature for 2 h. The resulting Li2C2B10H10 solution was then cooled to −78 °C, to which was added 2-indanone (1.37 g, 10.4 mmol) in one portion. The reaction mixture was stirred at −78 °C for 1 h, at −30 °C for 2 h, and then at room temperature overnight. This solution was quenched by adding 2 M hydrochloric acid (15 mL). The organic layer was separated and washed by water (15 mL), saturated NaHCO3 aqueous solution (15 mL), and brine (15 mL) and then dried with anhydrous Na2SO4. After removal of the solvent, column chromatographic separation (silicon gel, 230−400 mesh) using hexane/acetone (5:1 in v/v) as eluent afforded 1 (890 mg, 31%) and o-carborane (840 mg, 56%) all as a white solid. Recrystallization from n-hexane/diethyl ether gave X-ray-quality crystals of 1, mp 110−111 °C. 1H NMR (CDCl3):  δ 7.26 (m, 4H) (aromatic), 4.29 (s, 1H) (CH of cage), 3.52 (d, 2 J = 16.2 Hz, 2H) (CH 2), 2.97 (d, 2 J = 16.2 Hz, 2H) (CH 2), 2.42 (brs, 1H) (OH). 13C{1H} NMR (CDCl3):  δ 139.0, 127.5, 125.0 (aromatic H), 81.8, 80.1 (cage C), 59.4 (C-OH), 48.8 (CH2). 11B{1H} NMR (CDCl3):  δ −3.8 (2B), −9.3 (2B), −11.9 (2B), −13.7 (4B). IR (KBr, cm-1):  ν 3571 (brs), 3065 (s), 2627 (vs), 2579 (vs), 2549 (vs), 1479 (m), 1223 (m), 1184 (m), 1092 (m), 1049 (m), 748 (vs), 723 (s). Anal. Calcd for C11H20B10O (1):  C, 47.80; H, 7.29. Found:  C, 47.44; H, 7.31.

Preparation of 2-( o -Carboranyl)indene (2). Compound 1 (552 mg, 2.0 mmol) and p-TsOH (344 mg, 2.0 mmol) were mixed in a glass tube. The tube was sealed and heated at 180 °C for 10 min. The resulting black residue was dissolved in diethyl ether (10 mL). The solution was washed with water (15 mL), saturated NaHCO3 aqueous solution (15 mL), and brine (15 mL) and then dried with anhydrous Na2SO4. Removal of the solvent afforded a pale brown solid. Column chromatographic separation (silicon gel, 230−400 mesh) using hexane as eluent afforded 2 as a white solid (433 mg, 84%). IR (KBr, cm-1):  ν 3057 (s), 2607 (vs), 1457 (m), 1385 (m), 1065 (m), 1014 (m), 916 (m), 868 (m), 727 (s). Anal. Calcd for C11H18B10 (2):  C, 51.14; H, 7.02. Found:  C, 51.23; H 7.11.

The resulting Li2C2B10H10 solution was then cooled to −78 °C, to which was added indene epoxide (1.37 g, 10.4 mmol) in one portion. Preparation of 1-( o -Carboranyl)indene (4). Compound 3 (1.38 g, 5.0 mmol) was dissolved in 20 mL of toluene, to which was added triphenylphosphine (1.57 g, 6.0 mmol) and imidazole (680 mg, 10.0 mmol). The reaction mixture was stirred at room temperature for 1 h and heated to reflux for 48 h. The resulting solid was removed by filtration. Preparation of 2-(  o  -Carboranyl)-2-indanol (1). A 1.6 M solution of n-BuLi in n-hexane (13.0 mL, 20.8 mmol) was slowly added to a stirring solution of o-carborane (1.50 g, 10.4 mmol) in toluene/diethyl ether (2:1, 30 mL) at 0 °C, and the mixture was stirred at room temperature for 2 h. The resulting Li2C2B10H10 solution was then cooled to -78 °C, to which was added 2-indanone (1.37 g, 10.4 mmol) in one portion. The reaction mixture was stirred at -78 °C for 1 h, at -30 °C for 2 h, and then at room temperature overnight. This solution was quenched by adding 2 M hydrochloric acid (15 mL). The organic layer was separated and washed by water (15 mL), saturated NaHCO3 aqueous solution (15 mL), and brine (15 mL) and then dried with anhydrous Na2SO4. After removal of the solvent, column chromatographic separation (silicon gel, 230-400 mesh) using hexane/acetone (5:1 in v/v) as eluent afforded 1 (890 mg, 31%) and o-carborane (840 mg, 56%) all as a white solid. Recrystallization from n-hexane/diethyl ether gave X-ray-quality crystals of 1, mp 110-111 °C. 1H NMR (CDCl3): δ 7.26 (m, 4H) (aromatic), 4.29 (s, 1H) (CH of cage), 3.52 (d, 2 J = 16.2 Hz, 2H) (CH 2), 2.97 (d, 2 J = 16.2 Hz, 2H) (CH 2), 2.42 (brs, 1H) (OH). 13C{1H} NMR (CDCl3): δ 139.0, 127.5, 125.0 (aromatic H), 81.8, 80.1 (cage C), 59.4 (C-OH), 48.8 (CH2). 11B{1H} NMR (CDCl3): δ -3.8 (2B), -9.3 (2B), -11.9 (2B), -13.7 (4B). IR (KBr, cm-1): ν 3571 (brs), 3065 (s), 2627 (vs), 2579 (vs), 2549 (vs), 1479 (m), 1223 (m), 1184 (m), 1092 (m), 1049 (m), 748 (vs), 723 (s). Anal. Calcd for C11H20B10O (1): C, 47.80; H, 7.29. Found: C, 47.44; H, 7.31.

The resulting black residue was dissolved in diethyl ether (10 mL). The solution was washed with water (15 mL), saturated NaHCO3 aqueous solution (15 mL), and brine (15 mL) and then dried with anhydrous Na2SO4. Removal of the solvent afforded a pale brown solid. Column chromatographic separation (silicon gel, 230-400 mesh) using hexane as eluent afforded 2 as a white solid (433 mg, 84%).  Preparation of {[ η    5   : η    6   -(1-C  9  H  6  )(C  2  B  10  H  11  )Er(THF)]  2  (   μ  -BH  4  )}{Na(THF)  2  } ⋅ C  7  H  8   (8 ⋅ C  7  H  8  ). This complex was prepared as yellow crystals from Er(BH4)3(THF)3 (214 mg, 0.5 mmol) and 6 (343 mg, 0.25 mmol) using procedures identical to those used in the synthesis of 7a (234 mg 74%), mp 115 °C (dec). 1H NMR (pyridine-d 5): δ 3.62 (s), 1.52 (s) (THF), and many other unresolved peaks. 11B{1H} NMR (pyridine-d 5): many broad, unresolved resonances. IR (KBr, cm-1): ν 2966 (s), 2876 (s), 2533 (vs), 2440 (s), 1439 (s), 1375 (m), 1219 (m), 1139 (m), 1045 (s), 1003 (s), 904 (m), 852 (s), 750 (s), 680 (m). Anal.  Preparation of {[ η    5   : η    7   -(1-C  9  H  6  )(C  2  B  10  H  11  )Er(THF)]  2  }{Na  4  (THF)  8  }  (9). A suspension of 8⋅C7H8 (158 mg, 0.13 mmol) and finely cut sodium metal (46 mg, 2.0 mmol) in THF (5 mL) was stirred at room temperature for 2 days. After removal of excess Na metal, the clear solution was concentrated to ca. 3 mL, to which was added n-hexane (1 mL). Complex 9 was obtained as yellow crystals after this solution stood at room temperature for 2 days (141 mg, 68%), mp 162 °C (dec). 1H NMR (pyridine-d 5): δ 3.84 (s), 1.82 (s) (THF), and many other unresolved peaks. 11B{1H} NMR (pyridine-d 5): many broad, unresolved resonances.
